title: Georgian Together
description: This is a corpus which Georgian Together users can pull data from, and contribute to. To install the Georgian Together app, or find out more about it, visit the Google Play store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.github.opensourcefieldlinguistics.fielddb.lessons.georgian

terms.humanReadable: The materials included in this corpus are available for research and educational use. If you want to use the materials for commercial purposes, please notify the curators(s) of the corpus (batumi-apps@googlegroups.com) prior to the use of the materials. Users of this corpus can copy and redistribute the materials included in this corpus, under the condition that the materials copied/redistributed are properly attributed.  Modification of the data in any copied/redistributed work is not allowed unless the data source is properly cited and the details of the modification is clearly mentioned in the work. Some of the items included in this corpus may be subject to further access conditions specified by the owners of the data and/or the authors of the corpus.

license.title: Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike (CC BY-SA).
license.humanReadable: This license lets others remix, tweak, and build upon your work even for commercial purposes, as long as they credit you and license their new creations under the identical terms. This license is often compared to “copyleft” free and open source software licenses. All new works based on yours will carry the same license, so any derivatives will also allow commercial use. This is the license used by Wikipedia, and is recommended for materials that would benefit from incorporating content from Wikipedia and similarly licensed projects.

datumFields.help: This is a linguistics concept, for example you can put in sentences that are ungrammatical (no one would say, or is an impossible combination of words) and put a * in this field to indicate that its judgment is "impossible to say"
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: This is a linguistics concept, for example you can put in sentences that are ungrammatical (no one would say, or is an impossible combination of words) and put a * in this field to indicate that its judgment is "impossible to say"
datumFields.label: judgement

datumFields.help: The written form in Georgian letters. Example: მეგობარი
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: The written form in Georgian letters. Example: მეგობარი
datumFields.label: orthography

datumFields.help: This is an easy to read version of the example. It could be in a romanized (a-z) form, or real the written form or even in the phonetic alphabet (it depends on what your team wants to do).
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: This is an easy to read version of the example. It could be in a romanized (a-z) form, or real the written form or even in the phonetic alphabet (it depends on what your team wants to do).
datumFields.label: utterance

datumFields.help: Morphemes are prefixes and suffixes in the language. You can use this line to indicate them like this sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Morphemes are prefixes and suffixes in the language. You can use this line to indicate them like this sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: morphemes

datumFields.help: This is an optional field that is used by the system to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging conventions you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: This is an optional field that is used by the system to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging conventions you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.label: syntacticCategory

datumFields.help: A translation of each individual morpheme (above). This line is used by linguist and the system to help semi-automatically gloss your future examples. You don't have to provide it, it's optional. The linguists on the team can do it for you.  Sample entry: friend-FEM-PL
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: A translation of each individual morpheme (above). This line is used by linguist and the system to help semi-automatically gloss your future examples. You don't have to provide it, it's optional. The linguists on the team can do it for you.  Sample entry: friend-FEM-PL
datumFields.label: gloss

datumFields.help: This is a free translation into English. (See the Russsian field below for the Russian Translation) Sample entry: (female) friends
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: This is a free translation into English. (See the Russsian field below for the Russian Translation) Sample entry: (female) friends
datumFields.label: translation

datumFields.help: Это бесплатная перевести на русский язык. This is a free translate into Russian (for the users who come from Russian speaking areas). Example: друзья
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Это бесплатная перевести на русский язык. This is a free translate into Russian (for the users who come from Russian speaking areas). Example: друзья
datumFields.label: russian

datumFields.help: Additional details about the context where this example can be used. Example: (general purpose for female friends)
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Additional details about the context where this example can be used. Example: (general purpose for female friends)
datumFields.label: context

datumFields.help: Any number of tags of data validity which can help remember where you got the data, and how confident you are about where the example would be used (written, spoken etc). For example: ToBeCheckedWithSeberina, CheckedWithRicardo, CheckedWithGoogleTranslate, PublishedInNewspaper, Deleted etc...
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Any number of tags of data validity which can help remember where you got the data, and how confident you are about where the example would be used (written, spoken etc). For example: ToBeCheckedWithSeberina, CheckedWithRicardo, CheckedWithGoogleTranslate, PublishedInNewspaper, Deleted etc...
datumFields.label: validationStatus

datumFields.help: Tags for categorizing data into themes (Food, Transportation, Family) language learning lessons, or other info that you might want to use to categorize your data.
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Tags for categorizing data into themes (Food, Transportation, Family) language learning lessons, or other info that you might want to use to categorize your data.
datumFields.label: tags

datumFields.help: This optional field is used by the system to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: This optional field is used by the system to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.label: syntacticTreeLatex

datumFields.help: The user who originally entered the datum. (You cant modify this field)
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: The user who originally entered the datum. (You cant modify this field)
datumFields.label: enteredByUser

datumFields.help: An array of users who modified the datum. (You cant modify this field)
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: An array of users who modified the datum. (You cant modify this field)
datumFields.label: modifiedByUser

sessionFields.label: dialect
sessionFields.help: You can use this field to be as precise as you would like about the dialect of this session.

sessionFields.label: language
sessionFields.help: This is the langauge (or language family), if you would like to use it.

sessionFields.label: dateElicited
sessionFields.help: This is the date in which the session took place.

Modification of the data in any copied/redistributed work is not allowed unless the data source is properly cited and the details of the modification is clearly mentioned in the work.
